prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for sending my children to school rather than to their Grandfather’s burial?
My kids (6 & 9) grandfather on their father’s side passed away March 1st. Their father and I are divorced and not on the greatest terms but I loved my ex-FIL like my own Father. We were very close and at one point he and my ex-MIL even lived with us. He passed away after a long, hard battle with a relatively rare disorder.

His funeral home viewings were this past Friday, March 8th. The service and wake held for them was March 9th, Saturday. Because he was a Veteran the whole process was much slower as the veterans cemetery he wanted to be laid to rest has been extremely busy the last few weeks and the earliest he could be buried was today, Monday, March 11th.

My children missed school on Friday to be at both of the two viewings held. Being so young...they really had a hard time seeing their grandfather in his casket.  The weekend was difficult for them; he’s the first family member that they know very well to have passed away. They did a bit better at the wake but were still pretty emotional. Crying. It broke my heart.

Today he is being laid in his final resting place. A small handful of my ex’s family members will be there. It’s also a Monday and both my son and daughter have tests at school today. I asked them if they wanted to go to the burial; both shook their heads no. My son said that he had “already said goodbye to Pappy”. 

I sent them to school. I just received a phone call from my ex-MIL asking what time I would have the kids at the cemetery. I felt absolutely horrible telling her that the kids were in school and would not be attending the burial. She was *very* upset by this even after I explained that the kids themselves felt that they had already said goodbye. 

Am I the Asshole for not forcing my children to attend their Pappy’s burial? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let me try to work through this. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong for sending their kids to school instead of attending their grandfather's burial. 

First, I need to understand the situation. The kids are 6 and 9 years old. Their grandfather passed away, and the author is their mother, divorced from the kids' father. They had a close relationship with the grandfather, and the kids already attended viewings and a wake. The burial is on a Monday, and the kids have tests. The author asked if they wanted to go, and they declined, so she sent them to school. The ex-mother-in-law is upset, but the author is questioning if she's the asshole for not forcing the kids to attend.

Now, considering the kids' age and emotional state. They were already traumatized by seeing their grandfather in a casket and had a hard time dealing with the funeral events. Making them attend the burial might be too much for them, especially if they feel they've already said goodbye. The author respected their wishes, which is important for their emotional well-being.

The ex-MIL is upset, but the author isn't in a position to force the kids to go if it's not in their best interest. The kids' education also has tests, so there's a balance between family obligations and the children's needs. The author's decision prioritizes the kids' emotional health over attending the burial, which seems reasonable given their age and the circumstances.

I think the key points are the kids' well-being and their own decision to not attend. The author isn't in the wrong because she didn't push them to go against their will, especially when they were already struggling with the loss. The ex-MIL's upset is understandable but not a valid reason to make the kids attend if it would harm them emotionally. So the answer is B.
